Award.AwardTitle: On the Behavior of Solutions of Einstein's Equations and Other Geometric Nonlinear Partial Differential Equation Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
A good portion of this award is devoted to the study of the formation of singularities, both in solutions of Einstein's equations and in solutions of Ricci flow. For Einstein's equations, one of the key issues is Strong Cosmic Censorship ("SCC"): Is it true that the ubiquitous geodesic incompleteness predicted by the Hawking-Penrose theorems generically involve spacetime curvature (and therefore gravitational tidal) blowup? At least in certain families of spacetimes defined by isometries, the determination that the solutions exhibit "AVTD" behavior (dominance of time derivatives of the fields over space derivatives near the singularity) is a very helpful tool for studying SCC, and is interesting in its own right. Some of our work involves the development of a framework for proving that there are large sets of smooth (non-analytic) solutions in these families which show AVTD behavior. Our studies of singularities in Ricci flow have focused on those known as "neckpinches". We have, in particular, shown that there is a discretely parametrized family of Ricci flow solutions which develop "degenerate neckpinches", with the geometry asymptotically approaching a "Bryant soliton" at a prescribed rate (consistent with Type 2 behavior). These solutions are all rotationally symmetric. Wanting to know if the detailed asymptotic behavior seen in these solutions is also characteristic of non-rotationally symmetric solutions, we have chosen to first address this issue in the case of mean curvature flow ("MCF"), since MCF neckpinches share many features with those of Ricci flow, and since it is easier with MCF to compare non-rotationally symmetric solutions with rotationally symmetric ones.

In the projects discussed above, as well as in many others in my research program, the primary goal is to develop an understanding of the general behavior of large classes of solutions of complicated nonlinear systems of partial differential equations. Such equation systems, which play a major role in our modeling of physical phenomena at the terrestrial scale as well as at the astrophysical/cosmological scale, cannot be solved explicitly. However, using techniques such as those developed and used in this proposal, one can learn a tremendous amount of practical information about the behavior of solutions of these models, and therefore make very useful predictions regarding the behavior of the physical systems modeled by these equation systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported research in geometric analysis and general relativity which focused in five different areas

1) The behavior of cosmological solutions in the neighborhood of the Big Bang singularity: In this work, carried out with Florian Beyer and Ellery Ames and Philippe LeFoch, we showed that for an infinite dimensional family of solutions of Einstein's equations with two torus symmetry, AVTD behavior occurs as one approaches the Big Bang. This result is useful in studying the strong cosmic censorship conjecture.

2) Non-CMC solutions of the Einstein constraint equations: The conformal method has been very effective for constructing and parameterizing solutions of the Einstein constraint equations. Working with James Dilts, David Maxwell, Michael Holst, and Ralph Mazzeo, we have investigated the difficulties one has in extending the conformal method to non-CMC solutions. We showed that in many cases, the conformal method is ineffective. We found that for many sets of seed data, the conformal method either produces no solutions or multiple solutions.

3) The nature of "neck pinch singularities" in solutions of the Ricci flow equations: Dan Knopf, Natasa Sessum, Sigurd Angenent and I have used asymptotic methods to show that the type II neckpinch  singularities which arise in Ricci flow have very characteristic blowup behavior, with particular profiles in the neighborhood of the singularity.

4) The development of "type II singularities" in solutions of mean curvature flow on non-compact surfaces bounded inside cylinders: Using methods similar to those which we applied to the study of type II singularities in Ricci flow, Haotian Wu and I have shown that mean curvature flow behavior of non-compact surfaces bounded inside cylinders exhibit behavior very similar to that found in Ricci flow neck pinch type II singularities.

5) The behavior of symmetric solutions of "2-loop renormalization group flow": Ricci flow is the first-order approximation to renormalization group flow. The 2-loop approximation of renormalization group flow is governed by a PDE system which looks like the Ricci flow system, but with an extra term which is quadratic in the curvature on the right side of the equation. Working with Christine Guenther and Carsten Gimmre, we have studied the nature of solutions of the 2-loop renormalization group flow and compared them with solutions of the Ricci flow. We have found significant similarities and significant differences between the two flows.

In addition to the research mentioned above, this grant supported extensive work on three books. Two of them completed work on a series of four monographs on Ricci flow, carried out with nine collaborators. The other book, which was written with Abhay Ashtekar, Beverly Berger and other invited contributors, commemorated the Centennial anniversary of general relativity and reviewed the progress in gravitational physics over the 50 years.
